Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2009 11:59AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Jc, I have had 2 separate wire guided lumpectomies/biopsies. the size of the wire is about like the smallest string on the guitar. My first one, I went to radiology, they took the mammo, radiologist came in injected lidocaine and large needle, took additional pictures, inserted the wire through the needle, another picture, removed the needle, one more picture to make sure that wire stayed put, coiled up excess wire and taped to my breast. I was allowed to put my loose top back on without bra careful not to move wire. I walked myself to same day surgery where I was prepped for surgery and to surgery I went. My 2nd one started out the same but when I got to the check-in at same day surgery, they were out of beds and I was sent back to the waiting room until they had a bed opened. I waited in the waiting room for close to 3 hours before they finally called my name. I was just getting into bed and the nurses tried to put in my IV when the doctor came by to see how I was doing and he was ready for me. I wasn't quite preped completly but the nurses finished up quickly and I was in the OR in no time. (I do like my doctor, before any procedure he would come by the same day surgery area and ask if I or my family had any questions about what was going on, and when surgery was complete, he would personally go and talk to my family).

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2010 02:55PM lvtwoqlt wrote: I have had 3 sterotactic biopsies in a 24 month period. Has the doctor given you any valium to take the day of the procedure? My first one was done without and having to lay still on my stomach for 45 minutes had my back muscles feel like they were coiled like a snake ready to strike. For my 2nd and 3rd they gave me a script for 2 valium to take after I got to the hospital (with someone to drive me home ). Taking the valium made it easier for me. Some women say that it is painful, for me it wasn't that bad, the techs who were assisting the doctor kept reasurring me that I was doing fine. Once they gave the local, I didn't feel much pain. They described everything - including sounds - before they did anything. They gave me a small ice pack to keep against the area for an hour. I also wore a sports bra that day and the compression helps keep some of the swelling down. Sheila

Posts.Content: May 22, 2008 12:05AM - edited May 22, 2008 12:09AM by lvtwoqlt Patti, there are several things you can do to prevent LE, and no not everyone gets it after surgery but we are at a hight risk. Binney will post the sites that give specific info about preventing LE if she sees your request here. I know off hand that you don't want any blood pressure/blood draws/iv in the side where your surgery was performed. For those of us with bilateral, they must do this on our legs/feet. watch any cuts/scrapes/bug bites/sunburns on the affected side. If you have a cut/scrape etc. treat it like any wound, wash the affected area and use a clean dressing with antibacterial ointment. Use rubber gloves to wash dishes to keep hands out of the hot water. keep hands and arms moisturized drink plenty of water That is all I can think of now but Binney should be on soon to answer your questions better. Sheila edited to add: I found the site Binney always recommends http://www.lymphnet.org/ they have position papers that describe in detail what to do to protect yourself from lymphedema.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2008 11:34AM lvtwoqlt wrote: the Radiologist and doctor were very good at explaining what was going to happen prior to them doing anything so I would not start at any unknown noises. My sterotactic biopsies were performed with me lying face down with my boob in question through a hole in the table. It is important to get in as comfortable position that you can prior to them starting, you will be laying like that for up to 45 minutes. It (the boob) then was pressed gently with mammo type paddles and mammos taken from several angles. they will numb the area, then 'shot' the needle into the area of suspicision and vacuumed out a tissue sample. It is good to have some sort of anti-anxiety medicine to take prior like valium. The first time I had one done, it was done without the valium. It was not too bad but the next two were done with me on valium and it was much easier. Good luck on your tests. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 10:32AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Carolyn, I had family history of ovarian cancer  at a young age (aunt) and breast cancer post menopausal (mom). I had my first biopsy at age 44 on the left breast in feb 2005 showing ADH, my surgeon put me on 6 month mammo and cbe with him. He suggested tamox because of all the risk factors. I did not want to take it so he did not force the issue. 18 months later I had a 2nd biopsy but in the right breast for ADH, this time he said that I had to take the tamox and consider pbm, I could let him know if I decided to go with the surgery at my next appointment. I had severe night sweats/hot flashes and mood swings while on tamox (I could not take birth control pills earlier because of the mood swings) April 07 (6 months after starting tamox) I had my third abnormal mammo resulting in another biopsy of the right breast, this time it was early DCIS. Because of the vigilance of my doctor it was found before it had invaded the breast tissue (outside the duct). I am not saying that the tamox did not work, but as my doctor said the odds caught up with me. my hubby and I had decided that if I had to have another biopsy, I would do the pbm no matter what the results were. Because it was found early, I did not need chemo or rads but the last year of surgeries for recon have not been easy. It was a very hard decision to make but for me it was the best, I am not trying to tell you what to do but just giving my story to think about. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 12:49AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Zengardnz, I was dx two times (once in each breast) within 19 months with ADH and my surgeon suggested considering PMB. I was considering it and when I had my 6 month mammo it was abnormal again. I told him even before the stero biopsy that I wanted the PBM. He said that we needed to do the biopsy before scheduling the surgery. The biopsy the next week showed DCIS in the right breast and I did the bilat mast with recon June 07. I have not regretted my decision but am glad that the surgery took care of the cancer and did not have to have chemo or rads. The final path report showed more ADH in the right and hyperplaysic ductal cells in the left. My doctor said that I had made the right decision for me. It is a hard decision to make but like you, I wanted off the rollercoaster of 6 month mammos and biopsies. Make sure that you check out on the surgery forum the topic on shopping before and after surgery.  There are a lot of great ideas to help you recover from this surgery. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 06:21AM lvtwoqlt wrote: In 2001, my mom was given the choice of lump or mast with rads on either procedure, but when she asked the doctor her chances of recurrence with either procedure and she found out that the type of cancer she had would only be 25% with lump and less than 10% with mast, she chose the mast. It is an individual choice and is made when you are fully informed as to the recurrence rate for each procedure for you individually. Sheila
Posts.Title: what is best type of surgery? ckay ckay

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2007 05:36AM - edited Sep 27, 2007 05:36AM by lvtwoqlt Gemini, I have seen a good breast surgeon for all my proceedures because he is trained in problems with the breast.  Here is a link from this site that explains the sterotactic biopsy which is a needle core biopsy. http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/biopsy.jsp I have had 3 stero biopsies using mammogram technology and after we get the results from the biopsy, the surgeon will recommend the course of action to remove the mass. After the first 2 stero biopsies which showed Atypical Ductal Hyperplaysia (benign), I did have excisional surgery (lumpectomy) to remove the area surrounding the ADH. The last stero biopsy showed DCIS and I had bilateral mastectomy done because of the previous problems I had. The statics show that 80% of the biopsies performed are benign. Hope that this helps answer your questions. Sheila

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2008 01:27PM lvtwoqlt wrote: Robin, I had bilat with expanders last year and the last of my 4 drains were pulled on day 12 or 14 (I don't remember). I received camisoles from the hospital project camisole that had inside pockets to put the drains in. After the drains were pulled, I didn't need the camisoles any more but do wear them around the house just for comfort. I wore loose front buttoning blouses for several weeks. I did attend my father-in-law's funeral a week after my surgery in a nice slacks outfit with a loose fitting blouse and the camisole underneath (I still had 2 drains) and I still wear that outfit to work. People at the funeral were not even aware that I had drains. If they are doing the SNB you will probably have some range of motion problems and that is why the front button blouses are nice to have to wear. Sheila

I was 40 when my mom was dx with Breast cancer at age 60. It is perfectly normal to feel lost and confused when someone you love has this diagnosis. My mom's cancer was invasive and she had to have surgery, chemo and rads. I tried to help her through her journey. I was dx last year with non invasive BC and only needed the surgery (bilat mast). My mom and I have done the local Komen walk since 2001 together and this year will be our 2nd Relay for Life together. We walk the survivors lap together and the caregivers lap together. This has brought us closer together. Please talk to your mom about your feelings. Has anyone suggested genetic counseling for your mom and yourself? Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 01:27PM lvtwoqlt wrote: Kwoodson, I have had 3 sterotactic biopsies since 2005, the first one I was not offered any antianxiety meds. The doctor was very good and as Leaf said, he told me that if I felt any pain, he would stop and inject more numbing medicine. The last 2, the same surgeon did them and he prescribed 2 valium to take at the hospital after I signed the paperwork. I was more relaxed during those, 1) the valium helped and 2) I knew what to expect. Just try to relax while you are on the table and take a few deep cleansing breaths before they start and focus on your 'happy place' while they are doing the procedure. at the last one I even joked with the radiologist techs and the doctor about looking for Bill Murray to walk through the door and 'I got you Babe' to play on the radio (aka - Groundhog Day). I also used the ice pack that afternoon and the sports bra 24-7 for several days. good luck Friday sheila

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 09:05AM lvtwoqlt wrote: I have had 2 dx of ADH, once in each breast 18 months apart, my doctor after the biopsy showed ADH, recommended excisional biopsy/lumpectomy to remove the suspicious area and get a clean margin. He said that ADH and DCIS sometimes go hand in hand and he wanted to make sure that there was no DCIS component in that area.  After my 2nd dx of ADH my dr wanted to put me on either Tamox or Evista, but since I was pre-menopausal, Evista could not be given to me. Evista has proven to reduce the incidents of invasive bc in post-meno women who are high risk. I was put on tamox but 6 months later was dx with DCIS in the same area as the 2nd ADH. I was 46 when I had my bilat mast but kept my ovaries to protect my bones a little bit longer. Like Praying said, my husband told me, that I would rather have you here with fake boobs or without any boobs than the alternative. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2008 08:38AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Rafaela, I had SNB done bi-laterally last June 1, I asked about numbing the area and the radiologist at my hospital that was doing the injections (6 on each side) about numbing the area and he said that the lidocaine injections would 'dilute' the dye because it all goes to the lymph and he did not numb. I got through the injections by doing deep breathing and focusing on a point on the celing or opposite wall from where he was working (so I would not see the needles) and praying my way through it.  The radiologist is the one to ask about numbing the area. Posts.Title: IDC- stage 1 what next? marina1 iodine

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2008 05:07AM lvtwoqlt wrote: dukemom, I have had 3 sterotactic biopsies since 2005 for microcalcifications. My surgeon does the sterotactic biopsy first just because it is the least invasive. He though does prescribe valium to take after you get to the clinic where it is done, just to relieve the nerves while laying on the table, so if you get the valium, you will need somebody to drive you home. After the biopsy is removed (he takes 3 or 4 samples) they take an x-ray of the samples to make sure that the calcifications are there and another mammo of the breast to make sure that the correct area was tested. 2 of the 3 times I had ADH (pre-cancer) but the last time it was DCIS. They do the excisional biopsy afterwards if there is ADH or LCIS to make sure that there is nothing else lurking in the area that was missed by the stero biopsy. I hope that this helped you. Sheila
Posts.Title: Stereotactic vs. wire guided excisional biopsy? Dukemom2 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2007 11:22AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Koshka, I had my first abnormal mammo for microcalcifications Jan 4, 2005. I was called by my GP with appointment for diagnostic mammo the middle of Jan, and was back in my GP office by the 20th. They scheduled my appointment with the surgeon by the end of Jan. I had my stero biopsy Feb 14 which showed B-9 ADH. The wait did not change the outcome any. I did end up with the wire guided lumpectomy to remove the ADH on April 1. But my surgeon likes to do the least invasive proceedures first and if the stero showes problems then he moves to the invasive proceedures. One thing to remember 80% of the things that show up on mammo are B-9. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 02:02PM lvtwoqlt wrote: I had my bilat mast with the recon last June 1. My ps said that he gets better placement of the implant with the alloderm because the muscle will not cover 100% of the implant. Without the alloderm, the implant may migrate to the outer quadrant of the chest. I am 47 and don't find a lot of change in my range of motion but the 'foobs' do flex when I move my shoulders certain ways. I did take it easy all last summer while I let myself heal from the surgery. I don't think that my ps actually cut the muscle but sewed the alloderm to the bottom and outside part of the muscle to create the pocket. I had lymph nodes removed from each side so I am careful when lifting things to prevent lymphedema. Sheila

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2009 11:26AM lvtwoqlt wrote: I had my lumpectomies within 2 weeks of my biopsies and the same doctor did both procedures. When they do the sterotactic biopsy they insert a small clip at the point of the biopsy to show where it was taken from and to use it to show where the wire should be placed (if a wire guided lumpectomy is needed). The wire went in in approx the same area as the biopsy and the doctor uses that as a guide where the needle biopsy went in at. Sheila
Posts.Title: stereotactic biopsy NanceR NanceR

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2009 12:03PM - edited Apr 14, 2009 12:04PM by lvtwoqlt The stero biopsy and the wire guided lumpectomy are two different proceedures. They put the clip in at the time of the stero biopsy and IF they need to do a lumpectomy they then insert the wire at the point of the clip. I didn't mean to confuse you. The wire insertion is done the day of any needed excisional biopsies/lumpectomies. I had the wire sticking out of my breast the day of my excisional lumpectomy(ies) for a couple of hours. For the wire insertion they numbed the area and took mammo to determine where the clip was and inserted the wire into that area.  I had my first stero biopsy (left breast) done Feb 14, 2005, my lumpectomy April 1, 2005. I had my 2nd stero biopsy (right breast ) Aug 2006, lumpectomy Sept 2006, both times pre-cancer ADH. My last stero biopsy (right breast) Mar 2007 DCIS, and bilat mast June 1, 2007.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2008 07:14PM lvtwoqlt wrote: On walking I agree that casual walking may not be enough. I have an aerobic walking tape that I listen to while I am walking. It has songs that keep the beat going and force you to pick up the pace. It does start out with a slower song to warm you up and then goes into 'Louie, Louie', 'Heard it through the grapevine', and such that help to set a quick pace that you walk at for 20 minutes then another slower song to help in the 'cool down' portion of the walk. the tape itself is 30 minutes long and there are encouraging words over the music at different intervals that say, you are doing great, keep up your posture, check your pulse to make sure you are in your target zone, you have just trim-walked half a mile. I have a route around my neighborhood that try to walk on a regular basis. there is also an interval side to the tape where you walk 5 minutes slow and 5 minutes fast for the 30 minutes. Sheila

I have taken the olive leaf extract pills when I have yeast infections or sinus infections and it does help clear up these type of infections. The doctor said that I would just have to let it run it's course, about 4 weeks, to stop the cough. I started taking the olive leaf extract and the cough was gone in less than 2 weeks. I watch a program (your health) on FamilyNet with a holistic doctor who uses natural items to help heal along with the medicine. Sheila

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2009 10:31AM lvtwoqlt wrote: My doctor goes with the least invasive procedure first then if the results warrant, he does the excisional biopsy/lumpectomy. To help with the anxeity, ask for something for your nerves. I had 3 sterotactic biopsies in a 2 yr period and he would give me 2 valium to take after I got to the hospital to help me relax once I was on the table. And you can't see the needles when they are working on you. My doctor and the technicians were great in keeping me calm while they were doing the biopsy. The risk of the cancer 'seeding' through the needle track is not great and if it does turn out to be cancer the needle track will be removed in the subsquent lumpectomy. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 08:42AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Janice, I had 6 months to consider what I wanted to do. I have a family history of breast/ovarian cancer in my mom and aunt. I started in 2005 with an abnormal mammo needing a biopsy on the left breast which showed pre-cancer (ADH) and again 18 months later on the right breast showing ADH again. My surgeon asked me to consider preventative bilat mast after the 2nd dx of ADH but to let him know at my next appointment in 6 months. I went for that next mammo and it was abnormal again so my decision was made for me. I knew what my mom looked like after her single mast in 2001 without recon and I went with her to the local support group and made a lot of great friends there. They were willing to share their stories (just like on this board) as well as take me into an empty room and show me their battle scars so I would know what I would look like after surgery. I opted for recon with implants (not enough fat to create 2 nice sized boobs). My husband told me from the beginning that he didn't care what I did regarding my surgery/recon, he would rather have me here without my boobs than the alternative and he loves me regardless of my scars. I too, did my recon to make me feel good about myself and my body image. Sheila

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 03:05PM lvtwoqlt wrote: I have a family history of breast (mom) and ovarian (aunt) cancer, My mom did the genetic test and was brca negative. I had my first biopsy for calcifications at age 44 Feb 2005 that showed ADH in the left breast. My surgeon (who was also my mom's surgeon) put me on careful watch 6 month mammos and suggested tamox. 18 months later I had my second biopsy for ADH on my right breast, and was put on tamox. My surgeon suggested I consider pbm because his words 'It's not a matter of if but when you develop breast cancer'. My next 6 month mammo showed more calcifications in the right breast, even before the biopsy I told my surgeon I wanted these 'ticking time boobs' off. He said the insurance required biopsy of anything suspicious, it showed DCIS. I had a PBM done when I was 46. My final biopsy after the PBM showed more ADH in both the left and right breast tissue and my surgeon said that I made the right decision based on that path report. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 10:45AM - edited Jul 3, 2008 10:46AM by lvtwoqlt I learned the hard way about how many different foods contain soy. When my son was in the 5th grade he was dx with severe allergies, one of the top ones was soy. I took him off everything I could (In order of reactions shrimp (high), Soy (high), peanuts (high), milk (mild), yeast/mold (mild), chicken (mild), eggs (mild)) for 2 weeks, but when we went to McDonalds he ate a container of French Fries and had an allergic reaction (blood shot eyes) from the oil they fried the fries in before we left the restraunt. I started doing extensive research about what this boy could eat. I found out that Tuna packed in water can have 'vegetable protein' added (soy). Now they do list soy as the vegetable protein but then it was a try and see if he had a reaction. I was using Fleschmann's margarine because then it was 100% corn oil, about 1.5 yrs after his allergery alert, they changed the formula and added soy to their margarine. I then had to change to regular butter even with the milk allergy, it was less of a reaction than the soy margarines. Fortunately he has outgrown the allergy or has a milder reaction (he is now 23) and eats peanuts without any problem but has still avoided shrimp. Sheila

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2007 03:35PM lvtwoqlt wrote: Just take a breath and relax. Mammos are not that bad, the tech will start compressing and will ask if it hurts. they will stop when you say it is hurting. I was only bruised once and that was when they were doing a cone-compression with the old style machine. The digital mammos are much easier than the old style mammos in my opinion. The number of pictures will depend on what they are trying to see. Normally they do 3-4 on each side and they compress it less than 30 seconds for each pict. At the clinic I go to, after they take the picts, they escort you to the private waiting area in your drape while the radiologist checks the views. Sometimes they want additional shots if they did not come out clear enough. You could take some tylenol or asprin prior but I never found it necessary. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2008 10:36AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Mammo, ultra sound, and MRI show different aspects of the breast tissue. These are all screening methods to show possible problems that need to be checked out further. Three times in 24 months I had calcifications that don't show up under ultrasound but do show up in mammos and MRI. Each time required core biopsies of the areas of calcifications. The first two times it was ADH (pre-cancer) the last time DCIS. Here is my answers to your questions. What do I do about the lump? I would get the mammo done. How do I know the lump is still 'normal'? you don't know the lump is normal until the pathologist gets a sample (biopsy) of the lump and looks at it under the microscope. Why did the lump become a lump? don't know Why didn't the surgeon want the lump removed? Don't know but I would have insisted on further testing (mammo or MRI) and possible biopsy. When do I stop worring? For those of us who have heard the word 'cancer' the worry never completly goes away. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2008 11:44AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Nancy, the drains are not awful, just aggravating. I had bilat mast last June with the snb (blue dye) on both sides. my nodes were all negative. The dye injection is the worst part of the procedure and be aware that your urine will be a wonderful shade of blue/green after the procedure because your kidneys filtering out the dye. I came home with 4 drains (2 each side) and they have to be stripped and the output measured several times a day. After the output for 24 hours is down to 20-30cc per drain (my doctor's standards) they will be removed. It is good to have the towelettes with rubbing alcohol to strip the drains with. The nurses should show you the procedure. Sheila

Posts.Title: Excisional Biopsy...cosmetic questions? KnitWit ravdeb

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2008 12:21AM lvtwoqlt wrote: LB, the grade info is found on the path report after the biopsy.  It refers to the nuclear grade - how abnormal is the nucleus in the cancer cells. The more abnormal the nucleus the higher the grade. Grade 1 is low nuclear grade where grade 3 is the highest nuclear grade meaning more aggressive. The node is at the point of our mast/lumpectomies the doctor does a Sentinental lymph node test where they take a few of the nodes from the armpit that drain the breast area and test it to see if any cancer cells have escaped from the breast area. My node 0/7 means that they took 7 nodes and 0 nodes had cancer so my DCIS was confined. If you have any node positive you may need chemo. My mom had a single mast in 2001 for invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) I am not sure what her grade was but she had 15 nodes removed and 7 of them cancerious. But as I said earlier, she is doing great even with that many nodes showing cancer. Cathi said that she had a CA (cancer) dx in 06 in the left breast but had other lesions biopsied as b9 microcalcifications. I know these terms are confusing and you think you need to know everything at once. Remember we have been dealing with this for several years and have had plenty of time to learn the lingo. Deep breaths, Sheila

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2008 06:23AM - edited Nov 5, 2008 06:25AM by lvtwoqlt ADH is atypical ductal hyperplaysia - common terms - too many abnormal cells lining the duct. My doctor said that each time I was dx with ADH my risk factors increased. My history includes my maternal aunt dying with ovarian cancer at age 37 (1978), and my mom dx in 2001 at age 57 with invasive lobular breast cancer. When I had the firs dx of ADH in the left breast my doctor suggested I take tamoxiphen but I did not want the side effects that occur with that medicine. My surgeon put me on a 6 month mammo schedule and seeing him the week after my mammos to watch for any other changes. 18 months after my first dx, I had calcifications in the right breast which was the 2nd dx of ADH, he insisted that I take tamox and suggested I consider preventative bilat mast because of the family history it wasn't a matter of if I developed bc but when. 8 months after the 2nd dx, I had my 3rd abnormal mammo with calcifications, this time the biopsy showed DCIS in the right breast. My options were lumpectomy of the area with DCIS followed by radiation or the bilat mast and no rads. It was a hard decision but because I had the previous abnormal biopsies in both breasts I opted for bilat mast with implant reconstruction. that surgery was June 2007 and I am doing great. He even took me off the tamox because he said I had minimal breast tissue left and the benefit vs the side effects did not weigh heavily on the benefit side and I was having hard side effects from the tamox. My mom did a single mast, chemo and radiation for her cancer and is cancer free (dancing with NED) at this time. Make sure that you have someone with you to drive you home from the biopsy tomorrow, I couldn't walk straight from the valium when I got off the table. Sheila

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 11:33PM - edited Oct 8, 2007 11:37PM by lvtwoqlt Jackie, I was 46 at diagnosis. As a brief history,My mother was dx in 2001 with bc at age 60, her sister died from ovarian cancer in 1978 at age 37. My mom did the genetic test and was negative. I had abnormal mammo in Jan 2005 left breast biopsy showed DCIS, was put on 6 month mammo schedule. Abnormal mammo Aug 2006 right breast, biopsy showed ADH, suggested by surgeon bilat mast to prevent. April 2007 abnormal mammo right breast, biopsy DCIS. Decided to do bilat mast with expander recon June 1. final path report showed additional ADH in both breasts. I agreee with DDD. Bilateral mast is personal decision and the right one if you are comfortable with this decision. Because I did bilat I am not taking chemo or rads. Several people thought I was over reacting but I did not want this beast to get another chance and not catching it in the earliest stage possible. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2010 03:00PM - edited Jun 15, 2010 03:02PM by lvtwoqlt This is my take on the high prices of medical goods. The providers have agreements with the insurance companies that will discount the price to the 'allowable' price or agreed upon discount the insurance will be billed. Also most insurance plans have an 80/20 after you meet the deductible (insurance pays 80% you pay 20). Since the biggest part of the medical goods are paid for by insurance companies, the providers can charge a higher price to get a bigger profit. The woman in my area who sells mastectomy products will accept what insurance pays and writes off the difference, but if you are just into your new year, you have to pay 100%. I got a mast bra from her this spring for $50.00 since I hadn't met my deductible. Sheila

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 09:39AM lvtwoqlt wrote: This will not be part of the 'packing list', I liked everything that has been mentioned. This is more of a list of surviving after the bilat. Non-child-proof caps on meds opening the child-proof caps are very frustrating (experience speaking here). I had to send dh back to drug store to replace bottles/caps. See if you can get presc from doctor prior to hospital stay to prevent a stop on the way home. A note pad to keep track of when to take meds and when you took meds. Precautions to prevent constipation. the meds can mess you up quickly. Plenty of pillows at home to help you get comfortable in bed and in the recliner. Put things that you use in the kitchen frequently on the low shelves or even on the counter top. It is hard to reach much above shoulder level for a couple of days. Sheila

Posts.Title: Preventative Mastectomies? Goldie BethNY

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2008 01:38PM lvtwoqlt wrote: I too got camisoles to put the drains in and I wore tops that hung loosely on me. Here is a link to a picture of a jackson-pratt drain from wikipedia http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson-Pratt_drain The drains themselves hold about 8 oz of fluid and when full are about the size of your fist. After you empty the drains, they are squeezed as flat as you can get them to create a vacuum to pull the fluid out so they are not very big. I emptied mine 3 or 4 times a day and they were never more than half way full when I emptied them so they were not real big. I had 2 pulled a week after my surgery and the other two pulled the following week, when they put out less than 30cc in a 24 hour period. Sheila

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 01:12PM lvtwoqlt wrote: My history (family included), my maternal aunt was dx and died from ovarian cancer in 1978 at age 37, my mom was dx in 2001 with ILC at age 58. My mom did the genetic counseling and tested negative for the brca genes, but it is possible that there is something there that hasn't been identified yet. I was dx in 2005 at age 44 with ADH in the left breast, 2006 with ADH in the right breast, my surgeon suggested after the 2nd dx of ADH that I consider preventative bilat mast because of the family history and 2 dx of ADH contralaterally. Six months later dx with DCIS in the right breast. I did the bilat mast because I wanted to get off the rollercoaster ride. The final path report showed additional ADH in the right breast and Ductal Hyperplaysia in the left breast which neither showed up in the mammo. It is a hard decsision to make but you need to consider all the consequences of your individual decision, pro and con. Sheila

Posts.Content: May 11, 2009 11:42AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Motc, my first appointment did take an hour. He took my background/history on when I had my bc surgery and number of nodes removed, when I first noticed the swelling and what I was doing prior to noticing the swelling. He evaluated both arms to get the differences between the arms, he evaluated my gripping strength, force I could squeeze my fingers and thumbs together, hand/eye coordination to see how well my fingers could pick up pegs and put them in a peg board, he did range of motion testing on arms/shoulders, measured my hands/arms at points up each arm and compared the measurements. We talked about what I could and shouldn't be doing and set goals up for me to accomplish during my treatments, the first one being to reduce the swelling, 2nd to increase my exercise time, 3rd to increase my bicep strength. We decided to try the iscentoner glove for a week to see how much reduction we saw with little compression. My following appointments didn't take as long, mostly checking measurements to check progress. The wrapping isn't that bad. He only had me wrap half way up my forearm but to keep watch for swelling  in the unwrapped part of my arm. Sheila

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2009 04:44PM - edited Aug 10, 2009 04:46PM by lvtwoqlt Hi, jll18, I too have a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer (mother dx 2001 breast cancer, my aunt dx 1978 cancer of unknown origin - autopsy revealed ovarian cancer). I had 1 biopsy for suspicious microcalcifications on each breast 18 months apart starting at age 44 that showed pre-cancer ADH. After the 2nd biopsy and lumpectomy my surgeon suggested PBM for me because (his words) it wasn't a matter of if I developed bc, but a matter of when. I thought about it for 6 months and at my next mammo it again showed calcifications. This time the biopsy showed DCIS. I did the bilat mast and recon in 2007. I too struggle with low self-esteem. I frequently ask my hubby for reasurrance that he still loves me even with the major scars across my chest. Fortunately I came through all my surgeries without any complications. I think that we need to get some psychological assistance while we are going through this because our image is changing rapidly and emotionally it can be a challenge. It is a big thing for me to not have the feeling in my breasts also. My final path report indicated that I did make the right decision, it showed additional ADH in both breasts that didn't show up on my mammos. In the section of newly diagnosed (I think) there is a thread that has alot of the common abbreviations that we use when talking about our cancer. Sheila

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2010 06:55AM lvtwoqlt wrote: I was dx with ADH 5 yrs ago in my left breast. I have a strong family history of breast (mother) and ovarian (aunt) cancers. My surgeon didn't refer me to an oncologist but he is very knowledgable about breast cancer and suggested that I consider taking tamox. I was 44 and didn't want the menopause SE and didn't take it. 18 months later right before my 46th birthday I was dx with ADH again but in my right breast. My surgeon didn't make the tamox optional. I started taking it on my 46th birthday and had all the SE's of hot flashes, night sweats, leg cramps. He also wanted me to consider preventative bilat mast. 6 months later I was diagnosed with DCIS in my right breast. Run4urlife, The ALH or ADH that shows up on the needle biopsy but not the surgical biopsy may have been so small that the needle biopsy acually removed all of the abnormal cells. My last needle biopsy showed DCIS but my final path report didn't show DCIS but more ADH. That is how my surgeon explained the lack of DCIS cells in the final surgical path report. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 01:20AM - edited Jul 1, 2008 12:29AM by lvtwoqlt Donna, I just saw where you asked me a question 2 days ago. My calcifications were micro all 3 times. They did a sterotactic biopsy (needle with mammo assist) to get samples of the calcifications. When they showed up as ADH, my surgeon recommended a surgical 'lumpectomy' to remove the area surounding the calcifications to make sure that there was nothing else lurking in the area. I was then put on 6 month mammos and recommended taking tamoxifen. I have a strong family history of ovarian and breast cancer in first and 2nd degree relatives. After the 2nd biopsy in 18 months, my surgeon suggested thinking about preventative bilat mast and insisted that I take tamox. 6 months later my mammo was abnormal again and the biopsy showed DCIS still confined to the duct. I had bilat mast with recon June 1, 2007 and am glad that I did. my final path report showed additional ADH in the right side (pre-cancer) and pre-ADH in the left. I did not request my first path or mammo report but after my DCIS dx I have gotten copies of all reports and have a large expanding file that I am keeping them all in for future reference. Looking back I should have gotten reports from all earlier procedures to help me make the decision that I made. Sheila

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2008 10:30AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Lady Jane, I have a family history of breast and ovarian cancer but brca negative. I started having problems with my breasts that required biopsies in 2005 at age 44. First the left breast with pre-cancer ADH and the second time 18 months later the right breast with ADH also. I had 2 lumpectomies to remove the area surrounding the ADH. At that point my surgeon (who was also my mom's surgeon in 2001) suggested I consider preventative bilat mast. When I went back 6 months later with abnormal mammo on the right again and the biopsy showed DCIS grade 1. My surgeon wouldn't do anything until after the biopsy, and he asked me if I wanted the lumpectomy (again) with rads this time or bilat mast. I went straight for the bilat mast. I was tired of going to my mammos not knowing what would be found and there was only so much breast tissue that they could remove one piece at a time. I opted to go the way of the 2% or less chances bilat vs the 25%+ chances of lump with rads. CO1214 said that she had the lump and was ready to go to rads and decided on the mast and I have read other women on the board who have had the lumpectomy first and had chemo but before started rads, decided to forgo the rads and do the mast. I know that the decision is a hard one but you need to do what you personally can live with. We can only give you our opinions of what we did and why we made the decisions we made. Sheila

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2008 01:14PM - edited Dec 23, 2008 01:21PM by lvtwoqlt UPDATE!!! I just experimented with my directions for the pocket scarf and I have a few modifications. The width of the fabric 60 inches is not quite long enough for folding up to create the pockets. So . . . purchase 14-18 inches of the fleece instead of the 1/4 yard of fleece. trim off the selvage edges. fold the fabric in half to make a scarf 7-9 inches wide and sew across the end and up the side to the depth of the pocket you want on each end. You won't have to sew up the entire length of the scarf, just up to create the pocket. When you put on the scarf, keep it folded and put it on with the fold against your neck and the ends will fall approximately where your pockets are on your coat and your hands will slide into the pockets you have created without losing any of the length of the scarf. sheila

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2010 04:44PM - edited Jan 20, 2010 04:49PM by lvtwoqlt I had the same problem you are having now after my first lumpectomy, I was a 40C cup on one side and a 40A cup on the other. I did use the filler silicone prost (similar to a chicken cutlet in shape) to fill out my a-cup side to match my c-cup side prior to my bilat mast with recon. Please don't give up just yet. Check out your local mastectomy shop and look at the bras. Many of the specality bras do come in non-standard sizes (40A 40B) and I am now a 40B. My bras had cotton knit or microfiber pockets lining the bras that the prost fit into. Some of the bras linings have a 'moisture-wicking' properties that do help keep you cooler. Also check out www.breastfree.org for ideas to help you. Sheila

Posts.Content: lvtwoqlt wrote: I had a colonoscopy consult this past week with an internist. I had my pink wrist bands on and took my auto BP cuff with me, I asked the nurse if she could take BP on the leg, she looked at me like I had grown another head. I told her that I had BMX with nodes removed on both sides and with LE on the left side I didn't want to risk LE on the right side. I walked her through the steps to take BP with my cuff on the leg after laying flat for 5 minutes. My bp was relatitive high (due to waiting 2 hours after my appointment time before being called in to see the dr) and she said the dr would want to retake my bp since it was high. I continued to lay flat and when he came in with a manual bp cuff he asked what I was doing with the cuff on my leg. I told him bilat mast with nodes removed on both sides. He had me take my bp again with my machine and the bp was still elevated. He had me sit up and said he needed (insisted) to take my bp on the arm to make sure that my cuff was reading correctly. He totally ignored my pink wrist bands and my bp was still high. (was it high because of the pressure he put on me to take it the 'normal' way ) My colonoscopy is Wed. Monday when doing the pre-op I will tell them that will not have any IV or BP on my arms, if they can't guarantee this should I cancel the procedure? Sheila  Women are like tea bags, we don't know how strong we are until we were thrown into hot water. Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2007 04:52AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Libby, I am glad that the first confusing posts did not chase you away. this is a terrific site to get information from. I was dx with low grade DCIS April 2007 and I am one of the women who opted for bilat mast with recon. It is a personal decision and based on the level of comfort I was willing to deal with regarding possible recurrences. My history is 2 previous dx of Atypical Ductal hyperplaysia (once in each side) within 18 months and 6 months after the last dx of ADH, dx of DCIS. My surgeon suggested the bilateral mast last September after the 2nd dx of ADH. My mom is a 6 yr survivor of invasive BC and her sister died in 1978 of ovarian cancer. My mom was BRACA negative but I wanted some peace of mind and the bilat surgery gave me the peace of mind I was looking for. Good luck on your specific Breast Cancer journey. Sheila

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 09:06AM - edited Aug 11, 2009 09:31AM by lvtwoqlt Several years ago I started breaking out from most antiperspirants and I started using a gel deodorant (not antiperspirant) that I found only at WallyWorld. Well about 3 yrs ago they stopped selling that gel deodorant and I found the crystal stick. I purchased my first crystal almost 3 yrs ago (travel size) and it is almost too small to use now so I will have to go back to the GNC store and get another travel size stick. I use the crystal when I come right out of the shower and don't have to worry about running water over the crystal before applying it. I also have purchased the liquid roll on to use when I don't have water available (camping and such). Mine has a small bc ribbon on the top and the website said that a portion of the sale goes to Komen. http://www.tccd.com/ Sheila

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2008 08:54AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Kleenex. I had bilat and cords in both arms from my shoulders to my wrists about 3 months after my surgery. I did some stretching exercises - hold left arm out in front with palm forward, gently pull fingers back with the right hand and hold for 10-15 seconds, repeat with the other arm. I did this several times a day and it relieved the soreness with the cording. I never went to the surgeon with this, just did more stretches. It resolved itself in a couple of weeks. Sheila

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2009 08:00PM lvtwoqlt wrote: Carol, I had my bilat mast with the expanders put in at the same time, June 2007. My ps stated at my inital visit 'The good Lord took 13 yrs to create your first set of boobs, you need to give me at least 8 months!' I started my fills about 2 weeks after my surgery and had fills (60cc each fill) every 7 to 10 days through July and August. He allowed my expanders to 'rest' for 4 weeks before we talked about exchange. I went back after 4 weeks and requested one more fill in Sept. rested an additional 4 weeks, went back to talk exchange and had my exchange done in November to my perm implants. And then I had my nipples created just before Christmas (trying to get all done in 2007). I had my tattoos done in several stages from Feb to August 2008 (I didn't like the look from the first tattoo and sought out different artist in my area to fix problem) I didn't have any complications from any of my procedures but from what I have learned on the forum you need to allow time for conplications. Good luck on your expanders. Sheila

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 11:02AM - edited Apr 7, 2008 11:04AM by lvtwoqlt After my first failed mammo in 2005, I went to my gyn and she sent me to the surgeon for the next step in the diagnosis. My surgeon did not order MRI after my 3 failed mammo. I did not have any lumps only suspicious microcalcifications. I had sterotactic needle biopsies for each of them and they were not all on the same side. The first two times showed pre-cancer ADH but the last showed early DCIS. After my DCIS dx last april, my options were 1. MRI to see what was there before any further decisions were made or 2. mastectomy. If I chose single mast, he would have probably done the MRI to see if anything else was in the other breast to help make my decision, but I chose bilat mast. He then said that the MRI was a moot point because I had already decided to remove them both. I also had problems with my insurance denying part of my reconstruction, My PS and I appealed the denial for 6 months before it went to the independent PS review where it was deemed a common practice for the proceedure he used in the recon. Sheila

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2008 10:14PM lvtwoqlt wrote: I had 4 drains after my bilat mast with expanders. 2 of them were pulled on day 7 and the other 2 were pulled on day 11 or 12. When I had appointments for the first 2 weeks at the ps office, I would take a pain pill before leaving the house, it was a 30 minute drive across some rough roads and my m om was my designated driver for the first 3 weeks after surgery. I did not feel anything when they pulled the drains. I could not shower while I had the drains or wash my hair, fortunately my mom drove me to my hairdresser 3 days after surgery and she gave me a free wash and dry as well as a box lunch for myself and my mom (she attends church with us). After that, my sister came to the house a couple of times to wash my hair in the kitchen sink and help with the 'bird baths' to freshen me up until I could shower. Sometimes we need a little help from our friends to get us through the treatment, my hubby is long haul trucker and home weekends only. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2010 09:23AM lvtwoqlt wrote: I agree that the heat+humidity are deterrents for going outside in the summer. I have found that if I want to walk, I go out around 6:30 am (that is as early-bird as I want to go out) and walk aprox 1 mile. That way I can get my walk in and get a shower before I have to be at work at 8:00, I work about 1/2 mile from my house. The evenings are still too hot/humid to go out. I grew up in Ohio and the summers didn't seem to be that hot, we used to set up our camper (pop-up canvas) at a local campgrounds for several weeks at a time and Dad would go to work and we would stay there, playing in the creek all day. No AC available. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2008 03:53AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Let me add, I was 45 when I first heard of micro-calcifications. My doctor sent me straight to the surgeon for a biopsy, it was b-9 (pre-cancer ADH). I have a family history of an aunt with ovarian cancer in 1978 and my mom breast cancer in 2001. My surgeon put me on a 6 month mammo schedule along with seeing him at the same time for cbe. 18 months after the first ADH dx in the left breast, I had ADH dx in the right breast. my surgeon put me on tamox and suggested bi-lat mast. I took the tamox for 6 months and at my next mammo it was abnormal again on the right. The biopsy showed DCIS and I opted for the bilat mast June 07 and have not looked back. I am now 47 yrs old, my boy is 23. My biopsies were sterotactic biopsies, easier and cheaper to do than excisional biopsies until they found out what they were then I had excisional biopsies/lumpectomies to remove the area surrounding the calcifications. If you have any questions just post them, somebody will be able to answer them and calm your fears at the same time. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2008 04:18AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Summer, I for one don't think it is too radical. I did not do the mast with the first biopsy though. as I posted just above, I was put on the close watch (6 months) checkups. Now with the MRI it can be followed even closer. After my 2nd biopsy, my surgeon said it wasn't a matter of if but when I would be dx with bc. After my doctor suggested I think about pbm, I discussed it with my hubby for 6 months and we decided that if I had one more abnormal mammo - no matter what the biopsy showed - I wanted the "ticking-time-boobs" off. The final path report showed additonal areas of ADH in the right and pre-ADH in the left. For me it was the right decision, it would have returned later. Good luck on you stero biopsy tomorrow. Did they give you any meds to relax you during the procedure? Sheila

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2010 11:34AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Our local support group uses the day you got the word. I had my biopsy on Wednesday morning and the doctor said to expect the results in 24 to 48 hours. Friday afternoon at 3:20 I got a call on my cell phone, the nurse asked me if I was at home alone and I knew the results. Unfortunately I am on the switchboard at my job and the others in my dept (IT) leave at noon on Fridays (come in early through the week) and I was alone on the first floor. She gave me the 'good' news that it was low grade DCIS and the doctor would want to see me the following week and the front office would call me on Monday or Tuesday to set up the appointment. I immediately unplugged the console, called my husband and cried, called my mom and cried, went upstairs to a friends office and cried. I think I was away from the board for about 15 minutes. On Sunday morning, I was driving by and saw my bosses car in the lot (he was working on month-end reports) and stopped to tell him what was going on.

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2008 09:54AM lvtwoqlt wrote: I have had 2 excisional biopsies at two different times but both on Fridays. I was in the hospital same-day surgery unit about 9:00 am each time and home by 6:00 pm. They did put me out with a 'light' sedation. My surgeon put me in surgical bras at the time of the procedure that I wore 24-7 for 2 days then able to shower but put either that bra back on or a sports bra for the next 2 weeks 24-7. Sports bras that open in the front are the best ones to get, you may not want to raise your hands over your head to put on the other sports bras depending on where the incision is. They gave me prescript for vicoden but I took maybe 2-3 over the weekend. I was able to drive again and go back to work on Monday. I hope that this helps you. Good luck on your surgery. Sheila

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 01:28PM lvtwoqlt wrote: Thanks for all the info. I have actually put this off about 18 months (past my 50th birthday ), my general doctor's office has had some turn overs since September, including my doctor and several nurses, and the new doctor recommended I go for this test last October but the nurses dropped the ball to scheduling it. I went into the office last week to get a permission form filled out to take a survivors exercise class and I mentioned that I was not scheduled for one yet and they called me the next day saying that they had me scheduled for the consult the next day. . . not much time to research the doctor they sent me to.  I know I should have been more adamant that he not use my arm but I was so frustrated that my normally low (110/65) bp was 155/98. I have printed out several copies of the suso 'what we need our doctors, nurses . . . Lymphedema' and using my pink pen circling the important items for this procedure and also writing on the front page the specific sections so they can find it easy, and I will be handing them out on the day of the procedure. They are doing my pre-op over the phone tomorrow and I am going to insist that I speak to the anesthetist regarding my rights as a breast cancer patient and demand foot IV. I had a foot IV for my 2nd lumpectomy in 2006 at the hospital because I had a lumpectomy on the left side in 2005 and the 2nd lumpectomy was on the right side and the anesthestist at that hospital didn't have a problem doing that IV. I will also talk to the cancer support nurse to see if she can 'help' educate the doctors so in the future no one will have to jump through as many hoops as I am having to. I have stocked up on gatoraid and jello to help me get me through the day before. . . that is also the day of the next exercise class (chair yoga) and I think I will need the yoga for the next day. Sheila

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 04:05PM lvtwoqlt wrote: A month after my surgery, I was going into the PS office for a fill and I saw a woman leaving with pillows under her arms and the frightened look on her face. I followed her to the parking lot and asked if she had the bilat surgery. she turned and looked at me and said yes. I told her that I had it done a month earlier. she asked if it got any easier. I asked her what she had done that day, she said she got the drains pulled out. I said that if you got the drains out she was on the road to recovery. It does get easier after the drains are out. Sheila

Posts.Content: May 16, 2007 06:51AM lvtwoqlt wrote: I am a pro at this, I have had 3 in the last 2 years. If you are the least bit anxious, ask for valium to take about 30 minutes prior. The first one I had was the hardest, no valium. The last time (april 25) I joked with the ladies and the doctor about looking for Bill Murray (groundhog day). They know that you will be uncomfortable and will do their best to get you off the table asap. But don't move until they tell you to move. The first 2 times showed ADH this last one showed DCIS, having PBM June 1. I had enough stero biopsies.

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 02:55PM lvtwoqlt wrote: Vicki, my aunt died in 1978 at age 37 from ovarian cancer, my mom was dx with bc in 2001 at age 57. My mom talked to the genetic counselor and got the test covered by her insurance, her test showed no mutation. I, too, went through numerious mammo call backs for additional views since I turned 38 or 39. In Jan 2005 I had my annual mammo and had what I thought was going to be the usual call back showing cysts but this time it required a biopsy. I was 44 at the time and the biopsy showed ADH (pre-cancer) on the left breast. I had surgery to remove the area surrounding the ADH and was put on a 6 month mammo schedule. July 2006, I had my 2nd abnormal mammo requiring a biopsy, again it was ADH but in the right breast. Once again I went to the OR and had the area surgically removed. My surgeon suggested that I consider prof bilat mast because 'it isn't a matter of if but when it develops into breast cancer'. He gave me some information on the surgery and to think about it for 6 months and let him know at that appointment. The month before my appointment Oprah had Renee Seiler on her show and she discussed her preventative bilat mast due to numerious biopsies for ADH. That show helped me make my decision. BUT at my next mammo, more suspicious calcifications showed up on the right breast for the 2nd time and my decision was made. My doctor said since there were calcifications he had to do a biopsy again and the biopsy showed DCIS. I know this is long but wanted to share my story of why I did bilat mast. The final path report on the breast tissue removed at the mast showed more adh in both breasts that didn't show up on the mammo. Sheila

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 10:09AM lvtwoqlt wrote: If you are going for a lumpectomy, they will remove only part of the breast, if you are having a mastectomy they remove the breast. They will also probably do a SNB (sentinel node biopsy) to determine if it is in your lymph system. that is how it usually spreads to other parts of the body. How fast it grows depends on the grade of the cells, the lower the grade the slower growing. My personal experience with surgery, I had my biopsy April 25, and didn't have my mast until June 1. Usually a few weeks aren't going to change the results. Sheila

Posts.Content: May 14, 2008 04:27PM lvtwoqlt wrote: Dawn, I am one of the women who was dx with DCIS and chose the bilat mast with implant recon. Everyone has their own reasons for chosing the procedure that they go through with. In my case, my aunt was dx at age 38 with ovarian cancer and my mom at age 60 with BC. I had problems since 2005 when I was 44 with abnormal mammos resulting in sterotactic biopsies, first on the left breast in Feb 2005, second on the right breast in Aug 2006, each time showing ADH (pre-cancer cells). After my 2nd dx of ADH, my surgeon suggested I consider PBM and to let him know at my 6 month follow-up appointment. April 2007 at age 46 I had my 6 month mammo and it was abnormal again, the biopsy showed DCIS in the right breast. For me the bilateral mast was the only reasonable thing I could do. I was tired of going on the roller-coaster ride of abnormal mammo and biopsies and I was ready to get off the ride. Do I miss my natural breasts? you bet I do. Do I regret having the surgery last June? No because it reduced my risk on both sides to less than 1 % of developing into an invasive cancer. I was not going to give the cancer another chance to form and possibly not find it before it had invaded. After my mother's dx she had the genetic testing done and was found to be BRCA negative. I hope that this answers your questions as to why I chose the mast rather than another lumpectomy. Sheila

Who knows, I know that I was not going to give it another chance to rear it's ugly head and possibly be invasive. Sheila

My risk was higher because of 1st degree family member with bc and 2nd degree family member with ovarian cancer. After my first dx in 2005 my surgeon recommended mammos every 6 months and suggested tamox. I did not want to take the tamox because of the se's. After the 2nd dx (18 month later) I was put on the tamox. I asked then (fall 2006) about evista because evista has fewer se's than tamox. The STAR trial had just finished and they found that tamox and evista were both good but my surgeon checked with his sources and said that the evista was only approved for post meno women. I wanted to take the evista because of the fewer se's but he said that my only option was tamox. I can't tell you what to do but ask if the evista is approved for premeno women now. Sheila

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 03:21PM - edited Feb 6, 2008 03:22PM by lvtwoqlt diane, we have all been in your shoes. I guess I was forced to go out. Seven days after my bilat surgery last June, my father-in-law passed away from liver cancer. My sister came over and washed my hair in the kitchen sink several times while I still had the drains in. I attended the funeral (on day 9) with 2 drains still in, wearing a bright floral shirt and blue slacks (drains hidden under the clothing). Sure I was in a drug induced not feeling any pain (oxycodone) and ready to get back to bed afterwards but I got out. I only hoped that my Mother-in-law would understand me not wearing a dress. I did not have a dress that I could comfortably wear with the drains intact. Let your friends help you. My hubby is a long haul trucker and only home on weekends, so I was completly by myself during the week while recovering. My mom came by daily to make sure that I was ok and fixed me lunches. My sister called daily and either brought supper or took me to her house for supper 2 or 3 times a week. Friends from work called and brought meals to me and asked if they could help in any way. They wanted to be part of the recovery process. Sheila

Posts.Content: lvtwoqlt wrote: I had a colonoscopy consult this past week with an internist. I had my pink wrist bands on and took my auto BP cuff with me, I asked the nurse if she could take BP on the leg, she looked at me like I had grown another head. I told her that I had BMX with nodes removed on both sides and with LE on the left side I didn't want to risk LE on the right side. I walked her through the steps to take BP with my cuff on the leg after laying flat for 5 minutes. My bp was relatitive high (due to waiting 2 hours after my appointment time before being called in to see the dr) and she said the dr would want to retake my bp since it was high. I continued to lay flat and when he came in with a manual bp cuff he asked what I was doing with the cuff on my leg. I told him bilat mast with nodes removed on both sides. He had me take my bp again with my machine and the bp was still elevated. He had me sit up and said he needed (insisted) to take my bp on the arm to make sure that my cuff was reading correctly. He totally ignored my pink wrist bands and my bp was still high. (was it high because of the pressure he put on me to take it the 'normal' way ) My colonoscopy is Wed. Monday when doing the pre-op I will tell them that will not have any IV or BP on my arms, if they can't guarantee this should I cancel the procedure? Sheila  Women are like tea bags, we don't know how strong we are until we were thrown into hot water. Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 11:41AM - edited Sep 4, 2008 11:42AM by lvtwoqlt My pcp ordered the first mammos that I had but I got letters from the breast imaging center to remind me that it was time for my next mammo and I would call and schedule the next one. After my first abnormal mammo I went back to my pcp and he sent me back for additional views and scheduled me with the breast surgeon a couple of days after the diag mammo. My breast surgeon does the sterotactic biopsies in the radiology dept with some rad techs assisting and he decided from the mammo if the suspicious area needs biopsy and what type. After my first biopsy my surgeon had me doing mammos every 6 months and the breast imaging center needed orders from the surgeon to do the 6 month mammos. The radiologist reads the mammos and gives their report to the surgeon and he looks at the images and decides what needs to be done. Sheila

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2008 07:55AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Sylvia, I have gone through 3 stero biopsies since 2005 and your description was on the money. I too had bleeding problems with the first one. At least you had zanax, my first one was done without any tranquil meds, but the last 2 I had valium to take at the hospital after I signed the release forms. By my third one, I was expecting to see Bill Murray come in the room (aka groundhog day). Cindi and Teeko, the first 2 stero biopisies showed ADH (once in each breast 18 months apart). I was already a high risk due to mother with BC and aunt with OC. I had the surgical excision for each area after each biopsy. The first biopsy put me at a higher risk level and my surgeon suggested I take tamox in addition to 6 month mammo/follw ups with him. I declined the tamox since I was just 44 and I didn't want the menopausal symptoms. My 2nd biopsy 18 months later, the surgeon said that tamox was no longer optional so I was dealing with the hot flashes and night sweats. He suggested I think about preventative bilat mast and let him know on my next visit because in his opinion it was not a matter of if i developed BC but when. Unfortunately my next mammo was abnormal again, the thrid biopsy showed DCIS. I did the bilat and the entire section of DCIS was removed in the stero biopsy but I had additional ADH in both breasts that did not show up on the mammos. Good luck on all your tests and surgeries. Sheila
Posts.Title: stereotactic breast biopsy teeko teeko

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2008 09:16AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Cindi, I had 2 previous biopsies for ADH (once in each breast) before my dx of DCIS. Each time you have this dx it does increase your stasticial chances for developing bc. I have a family history of pre-menopausal ovarian cancer in my aunt and post menopausal breast cancer in my mom (but she was on hrt). I had to put this into my equasion for deciding to remove my breasts. The wire guided lumpectomies are not that bad, I had 2 of them. My wires were put in at the radiology dept. They do a mammo to determine where the ADH is and the radiologist numbs the area and uses the picts to see where the needle (like IV needle) needs to go and inserts it into the area, they take another mammo to see if the needle is in the right location before sliding the small gauge wire into the needle. After that, they removed the needle and took another pict to make sure that the wire was still in the correct area. The excess wire was looped and taped to my chest under a gauze pad and took me to the same day surgery unit where I was preped for surgery. Sheila

Posts.Content: May 17, 2010 09:34AM lvtwoqlt wrote: surgery - bilat with TEs. dressings - came home with the ironmaiden surgical bra on and heavy gauze pads taped everywhere over the incisions. My instructions, don't touch the bandages until I saw the ps 3 days after surgery.  The follow-up appointment, dressings and tape removed, replaced with large gauze pad inserted into the ironmaid bra to hold gauze in place. no showers until after all drains removed, 2 weeks. I did bird baths with assistance from my mom and sister. Hair, my hairdresser washed and dried my hair 4 days after surgery for free. My sister came over and helped me wash my hair a couple times in the kitchen sink until I was able to take a shower, by then I could raise my arms enough to wash my hair.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2010 02:04PM lvtwoqlt wrote: In Feb I drove/rode with my parents from NC to Ohio. I made sure that I had a pillow to put under my arm when I was riding in the back seat (passenger side) to keep my hand elevated more than just resting it in my lap. I also used it on the arm rest when I was driving to elevate that arm more than just the arm rest. The small pillow I use is one I made from the sleeve from a discarded men's long sleeve dress shirt. I cut the cuff off and sewed the cuff end and placket shut. If the top of the sleeve is too wide, you can sew the seam up a little bit to make it look more like a long straight tube and trim the cap of the sleeve off to make it straight across that end. Turn it right side out and stuff it with fiberfill to the firmness you like and sew the end up. You can even take the other sleeve and make a 'pillowcase' out of it so if it gets dirty, it is easier to wash than the whole pillow. I didn't make a cover for my first one made out of a white dress shirt and it has gotten dirty. I think I will try another and just move the stuffing from one to the other . Sheila

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2008 04:09PM - edited Dec 18, 2008 04:10PM by lvtwoqlt If you have a few sewing skills you can also make a polar fleece scarf with the pockets. The fleece is usually 60 inches wide, just purchase fabric the width you want your scarf to be (1/4 yd would make it 9 inches wide), trim off the selvage edge and fold up the ends 8 inches or how ever deep you want the pockets and sew up the sides, it can be sewn on the machine or with a decorative hand stitch and embroidery floss. You don't even need to hem the ends or sides. In most cases the scarf is long enough to wrap around your neck and still put your hands in the pockets. the 'mitts' that Binney suggested can also be made out of polar fleece with a little bit of sewing skills. Right now is a good time to get the fleece, the Hancock Fabric stores are running a big sale on fleece right now.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 07:16AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Mommysta, Let me preface my comments with my family history as well as my history. My aunt (37 yr old) was dx with metstatic cancer of unknown orgin in 1978 and the autopsy showed ovarian cancer. My mom was dx with breast cancer in 2001 (age 60) had genetic test done and was BRCA negative. I started having abnormal mammos in my early 40's, first one that required biopsy age 44, showed ADH in the left breast. I saw the same surgeon that my mother saw, he put me on close watch mammo schedule every 6 months, suggested tamox at that point. I declined the prescription. 18 months later abnormal mammo on the right with biopsy showing ADH. Doctor insisted taking tamox and consider PBM but to think about it for 6 months. I went on tamox on my 46 birthday. I had what I would consider severe side effects (mood swings). On my next 6 month mammo, it was abnormal again on the right side. I opted for the PBM and my doctor took me off the tamox. My final path report showed more ADH in both the right and the left breast that didn't show up on the mammo. I am not saying that this is a normal scenario. Not all ADH will develop into DCIS or invasive cancer. I personally was tired of the rollercoaster of emotions regarding all the mammo/biopsies that I went through in just over 2 yrs. Sheila

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 11:19AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Clueless, Sorry to hear about your divorce. My first excisional biopsy was done behind the areola. All that showed was a small scar across the top - not really noticable after a while - and as a perk, I ended up with a small lift on that side . The second excisional was done on the other breast but that was on the out side of the other breast and I had a small (about 2 in) scar but it too faded in time. You will be able to do this. Just take everything one step at a time. Make sure that you follow the post surgery instructions, If you think you will have pain, take the pain meds before you start hurting, it is better to stay ahead of the pain than try to catch up with it. Also get copies of your path report - even if benign - and start a file with them. I did and I have reports from 2005, 2006, and my final surgery in 2007. It helps to track what is going on and helps with the decision making later on. Sheila

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 11:37AM lvtwoqlt wrote: After my first lumpectomy for ADH at age 44, I was about 2 cup sizes different. I qualified for my insurance to cover bras and prosthetics. I went to a professional fitter and she fit me with several bras and a thin silicone prost. to put in the pocket in the bras to even me out. This is an option if you don't want to lose your breasts. Because I had ADH the first two times (once in each breast) 18 months apart, when I was dx last year with DCIS at age 47, I opted for bilat mast just because I did not want to wait for a recurrence to be more invasive. It is not an easy decision and you are the only one able to make the decision for yourself, because you will have to live with that decision, not the doctor. Sheila

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 02:46PM lvtwoqlt wrote: My first two sterotactic biopsies (2005 and 2006) I didn't get the results (ADH) until my follow-up appointment about 2 weeks after the biopsy. My third biopsy (2007), my surgeon told me in the sterotactic room, we will call you with the results tomorrow afternoon (thursday). I called Thursday and they didn't have the results from the path lab but scheduled me for my follow-up 3 weeks later - first available appointment. Friday afternoon they called me with the path report on my cell phone. The nurse asked me first if I was at home alone. Fortunately I was at work. I got the news that it was DCIS with low nuclear grade. I don't know if he wanted to have the results phoned to me because he suspected it was cancer or they had changed the office policy to phone the results. And they did reschedule my follow-up to the following week.

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 01:43PM - edited Sep 15, 2008 01:44PM by lvtwoqlt My surgery was on Friday and before I went back to the doctor if I thought he was going to pull the drains that day, I took one of my pain pills just as a precaution. I came home with 4 drains and had them pulled 2 different days. My ps told me on my first post op appointment on monday to not empty them for 24 hours prior to my next appointment later in the week so he could get an accurate measure of my out-put even though I was recording the output each time I emptied them. By Thurs. I had 2 that were under 20cc but the other two were still over 50 so I only lost 2 the first week and the other two the next week. For me the path report wasn't back until the 2nd appointment, alot depends on the path dept and their protocol. Sheila

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2008 12:23PM lvtwoqlt wrote: The DCIS was in the same area as the 2nd ADH in the right outerquadrant of my right breast. My surgeon suggested I think about doing the preventative bilat after the 2nd dx of ADH as well as putting me on tamox. He said that my biggest threat was my mom even though she tested negative for the BRCA gene, they don't know all the genes that cause BC. My surgeon likes to do excisional biopsies after a dx of adh from the stero biopsy because the stero biopsy just gets a sample of the area and there may be something else lurking in that same area. I didn't ask him what the chances were that they would find anything else during the excisional. I had 6 months to think about doing the bilat after it was suggested to me before I had to make the hard decision. I am doing great, it took about 9 months to a year to complete the reconstruction process with implants and I am very happy with the outcome. Because I didn't have any invasive component and no lymph node involvment, I didn't need chemo or rads. Sheila

Posts.Content: May 25, 2007 10:56AM lvtwoqlt wrote: I will be having a double mast with recon next week and I don't know how long before you can wear the breast forms but I can answer the question about purchase of the breast prosthesis and bras. If your doctor writes a prescription for the mastectomy products and since you have had breast surgery, the insurance should cover the costs. To find where to purchase them you can ask other BC survivors in your area where they purchase theirs. The products are usually available at medical supply stores or in larger cities there are speciality stores that deal with mastectomy patients and are excellent at fitting. you can look in the yellow pages under mastectomy apparel for stores in your area.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 06:28AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Jan, I have a mother who was dx with breast cancer in 2001 and didn't have the brca mutation, her sister passed away from ovarian cancer in 1978. I was dx with ADH in Jan 2005 on the left breast at age 44, my dr suggested I consider tamox because of the higher than average risk factors that included my family history of bc and oc. I declined taking it because of the side effects and chose close surveillance (6 month mammo/and follow up appt with my doctor). July 2006, I was dx with ADH in the right breast and my doctor insisted I take it. This was before the CYP2D6 test that determines if your body metabolizes the tamox efficently.  I put up with the hot flashes/night sweats and extreme mood swings for 6 months. In April 2008 I was dx with DCIS in the right breast. What I am trying to say is nobody knows who the tamox is going to work for to prevent the formations of the calcifications. I would only be second guessing myself that if I started taking the tamox in 2005 would I not have been dx with DCIS in 2007. Sheila
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen concerns - patient with Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia JanW wallace101

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2009 08:49AM lvtwoqlt wrote: Mommysta, My path report from both stero biopsy and excision biopsy in 2005 left breast just read ADH clean margins after the excision biopsy. the path report from stero biopsy and excision biopsy in 2006 right breast just read ADH clean margins after the excision. The path report from stero biopsy 2007 right breast showed DCIS, final path report after bilat mast showed Hyperplaysic Ductal cells and ADH in the left breast as well as the right breast but I don't know the exact location of the ADH from the final path report. The DCIS that was found was in the same area as the ADH 6 months earlier. I don't know if it 'turned' from ADH to DCIS or not. My family history of breast and ovarian cancer as well as 2 previous abnormal biopsies put me in the high risk category for developing breast cancer. The surgeon that was my doctor is the most informed surgeon in this area on breast cancer treatments and I trusted him when he said in 2006 it wasn't a matter of if I developed breast cancer but when. He couldn't tell me if the DCIS was directly related to the previous ADH or if I started the tamox in 2005 it would have prevented my DCIS diagnosis. But he did say based on the final path report that I had made the right decision for myself. Sheila
